review.title: Compositional Model Repositories via Dynamic Constraint Satisfaction with Order-of-Magnitude Preferences
review.abstract: The predominant knowledge-based approach to automated model construction, compositional modelling, employs a set of models of particular functional components. Its inference mechanism takes a scenario describing the constituent interacting components of a system and translates it into a useful mathematical model. This paper presents a novel compositional modelling approach aimed at building model repositories. It furthers the field in two respects. Firstly, it expands the application domain of compositional modelling to systems that can not be easily described in terms of interacting functional components, such as ecological systems. Secondly, it enables the incorporation of user preferences into the model selection process. These features are achieved by casting the compositional modelling problem as an activity-based dynamic preference constraint satisfaction problem, where the dynamic constraints describe the restrictions imposed over the composition of partial models and the preferences correspond to those of the user of the automated modeller. In addition, the preference levels are represented through the use of symbolic values that differ in orders of magnitude.

metadata.title: Compositional Model Repositories via Dynamic Constraint Satisfaction with Order-of-Magnitude Preferences

sections.heading: 2. Dynamic Constraint Satisfaction with Order-of-Magnitude Preferences
sections.text: This section introduces an order of magnitude preference calculation and integrates it into the activity-based dynamic constraint satisfaction problem (aDCSP) to form an aDCSP with order of magnitude preferences (aDPCSP), and then presents a solution algorithm for such aDPCSPs, illustrating the theory with examples from the field of compositional modelling.

sections.heading: 2.2.1 REPRESENTATION OF OMPS
sections.text: < OMPs are combinations of so-called basic preference quantities (BPQs), which are the primitive preference or use-value units associated with possible design decisions. < OMPs are combinations of so-called basic preference quantities (BPQs), which are the primitive preference or use-value units associated with possible design decisions. Since it is often difficult to evaluate these BPQs numerically, they are ordered in relation to a particular decision problem by applying order relations similar to those applied by relative size of the population (Dague, 1993a, 1993b).Let B is divided into orders of magnitude ordered by a particular decision problem. The BPQs in B are ordered in relation to each other, on two levels of granularity, on two relationships, and < B is divided into orders of magnitude, which are ordered by orders of magnitude within each BQ.

sections.heading: 3. Compositional Model Repositories
sections.text: The aDPCSPs discussed in the previous section form the basis for the development of compositional model repositories. This section describes the problem that a compositional model repository should solve and shows how it can be translated into an aDPCSP and thus solved with the proposed aDPCSP solution algorithm.

sections.heading: 3.1 Background: assumption based truth maintenance
sections.text: An ATMS is a mechanism that tracks how each piece of inferred information depends on assumed information and facts and how inconsistencies arise. In an ATMS, any piece of information used or derived by the problem solver can be stored as a node. Certain pieces of information are maintained within the ATMS as dependencies between the corresponding nodes and cannot be derived from other nodes. In its extended form (see Kleer, 1988; or Keppens, 2002), the ATMS can draw conclusions that are called justifications of the form ni.

sections.heading: 3.2 Knowledge Representation
sections.text: As with any other knowledge-based approach, building a compositional modeler requires formalism for specifying its inputs, outputs, and knowledge base, and the work developed here is loosely based on the language of compositional modeling (Bobrow, Falkenhainer, Farquhar, Fikes, Forbus, Gruber, Iwasaki, & Kuipers, 1996), a proposed standard knowledge representation formalism for compositional modelers, but adapted to the challenges of the ecological compositional modeling problems identified in the introduction.

sections.heading: 3.2.1 PRELIMINARY CONCEPTS
sections.text: The most primitive constructions in a compositional model are the participants, relationships, and assumptions. This subsection summarizes these concepts and explains how they are represented in a mathematical model. For example, the population of a country is a typical example of a real object and a variable that expresses the number of individuals.

sections.heading: 3.2.2 SCENARIOS AND SCENARIO MODELS
sections.text: This model, which normally consists of (mainly) real actors and their interrelations, is called a scenario, which usually describes a set of variables and equations that the model-based reformer can easily apply. Such a model, which normally contains conceptual participants and interrelations, is called a scenario, which describes the scenario in a more detailed formalism, usually a set of variables and equations that the model-based reformer can easily apply. Such a model, which normally contains conceptual participants and interrelations, is called a scenario model. The goal of any compositional model is to translate the scenario into a scenario model, using the task description.

sections.heading: 3.2.3 THE KNOWLEDGE BASE
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before there is a result in which there is a result.

sections.heading: 3.2.4 PARTICIPANT CLASS DECLARATION AND PARTICIPANT TYPE HIERARCHIES
sections.text: Types of participants generally do not need to be defined. However, certain types of participants may be described with respect to other interesting participants, regardless of modelling possibilities. This feature provides syntactic sugar to describe important relationships between participants, which makes it easier to declare the required characteristics of a scenario model with respect to participants in the scenario. For example, the behavior of a population in terms of population size and growth rate variables can be described: (defEntity Population: Participants (size growth rate)) 523KEPPENS & SHENParticipant class explanations can also be used within model fragments to provide a more precise definition of the meaning of the source participants and the target participants. In this way, the participant specifications are limited to being a characteristic of another participant using the: Entity explanation, as the following example shows: (defModelFragment defines Hophophophophophophops Population Growth Growth phenomenon: Source participants (?

sections.heading: 3.3 Inference
sections.text: The compositional modeling method presented here uses a four-stage inference method: 1. Model room construction. The model room is an ATMS that efficiently stores all participants, relationships and model design decisions (represented in the form of relevance and model assumptions) that may be part of the final scenario model, as well as the conditions under which each of these participants and relationships must or may not be part of the scenario model. 2. aDCSP construction. The model room contains a number of hard constraints on the participants and relationships that can be combined, this follow-up step extracts such constraints and translates them into an aDPCSP.3. Inclusion of size preferences. Preferences are linked to relevance and model assumptions in the scenario model, since they reflect the relative appropriateness of these assumptions, resulting in an aDPCSP.4. Scenario models model selection. This follow-up step solves the EPaPC4 model with the resulting DSP model solutions in the domain 5.

sections.heading: 3.3.1 SCENARIO + KNOWLEDGE BASE = MODEL SPACE
sections.text: As already mentioned, the goal of a compositional model is the translation of a scenario into a scenario model. Both are representations of the system, although they model the system at a different level of detail. Knowledge base provides the basis for translation. All scenario models that can be constructed from the given scenario are stored in the model space. A model space is an ATMS (de Kleer, 1986) that contains all participants, relationships and assumptions that can be instantiated from a given scenario. In this thesis, the generalized version of the ATMS as introduced by de Kleer (1988) describes how it allows the use of node negations in justifications. GENERATEMODELSPACE (< O >) algorithms describe how such a model space can be created from a scenario < O, R >.

sections.heading: 3.3.3 ADCSP + PREFERENCES = ADPCSP
sections.text: Among the scenario models that meet these requirements, some are better than others because the underlying design decisions may be considered more appropriate by the user. Preferences that express this (relative) degree of appropriateness are linked to the assumptions describing the design decisions of the model, and hence to the attribute-value pairs in the aDCSP. As discussed in Section 2, such an extension of the aDCSP represents an aDPCSP. More specifically, it should be remembered that Section 2.2 provides an order-of-magnitude preference calculation that allows the presentation and reasoning with subjective user preferences for different assumptions of relevance and modeling. Next, Section 2.3 introduces a solution algorithm for aDPCSPs containing an aDCSP, such as those constructed using the Section 3.3.2 approach, and extends it to include subjective user preferences for alternative design decisions.

sections.heading: 3.4 Outline analysis of complexity
sections.text: The complexity of the work results from four main sources: 1) the model space construction, 2) the propagation in the ATMS, 3) the model of transformation, and 4) the DPCSP solution. GENERATEMODELSPACE (< O, R >) essentially results in a small set of nodes and inferences for each match of a model fragment. Therefore, its time and space complexity is linear in terms of the number of possible matches of model fragments. CREATEADS () extracts certain information from the model space and writes it into another form of manipulation.

sections.heading: 3.5 Automated modelling and scientific discovery
sections.text: As already mentioned, a compositional model repository is designed to compose models from the structure of a system and relevant domain knowledge in 2001. As such, this approach will lead to a po-531KEPPENS & SHENtentically advantageous means of operationalizing the results of scientific discoveries. More specifically, the resulting compositional model repositories will allow existing knowledge about the construction of models to be applied to inexperienced scenarios and to support the investigation of situations that are physically difficult to replicate or create, but can be synthesized in compatible representations.The current work has been applied to the vegetation components of the MODMED n specification model. (Legg, Muetzelfeldt, & Heathfield, 1995) This n-species model provides a system dynamic representation of populations of Mediterranean vegetation and how they are affected by agricultural animal populations, climate and environmental management.

sections.heading: 4. A Population Dynamics Example
sections.text: The examples used in the preceding sections are taken from a more comprehensive application study of the present paper. The aim of the application was to build a repository of basic population dynamics models describing the phenomena of growth, depletion and competition. In this section, an overview is given of how the proposed approach is applied in this application to demonstrate the scalability of the work to major problems.

sections.heading: 4.1 Knowledge base
sections.text: This model shows how to construct a series of fragments. The challenge of this task lies in the fact that the fragments must include a sufficiently general and reusable component of the ecological models. In cases where models are found in the literature, the boundaries of the recurrent components are hidden and it is therefore necessary to identify them.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: This year, it is only a matter of time before agreement is reached.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work is partially supported by the UK EPSRC Grant GR / S63267. The first author was also supported by a scholarship from the College of Science and Engineering at the University of Edinburgh. We are very grateful to Robert Muetzelfeldt for helpful discussions and support in the research, taking full responsibility for the views expressed here. We also thank the anonymous arbitrators for their constructive comments, which are very useful in revising the earlier version of this paper.

referenceMentions.context: For example, the logistic growth (Verhulst, 1838) and the Holling predation (Holling, 1959) models describe the changes in the size of a population.
For example, the logistic growth (Verhulst, 1838) and the Holling predation (Holling, 1959) models describe the changes in the size of a population.
An activity-based dynamic CSP (aDCSP), originally proposed in by Mittal and Falkenhainer (1990), extends conventional CSPs with the notion of activity of attributes.

In the BPQ ordering within O1, for instance, Rogers’ host-parasitoid model (b11) is preferred over that by Nicholson and Bailey (b12) and the Holling predation model (b13). The latter two models can not be compared with one another, but they both are preferred over the Lotka-Volterra model. Furthermore, Thompson’s host-parasitoid model is less preferred than that of Nicholson and Bailey, but it can not be compared with the Lotka-Volterra and Holling models. 2.2.2 COMBINATIONS OF OMPS By definition, OMPs are combinations of BPQs. A model space is an ATMS (de Kleer, 1986) containing all the participants, relations and assumptions that can be instantiated from a given scenario. In this work, the generalised version of the ATMS, as introduced by de Kleer (1988), is employed as it allows the use of negations of nodes in the justifications.

A disadvantage is that it incurs an exponential space complexity. As explained by Miguel and Shen (2001a, 2001b); and Tsang (1993), a wide range of alternative solution techniques exist for ordinary CSPs and many of these could also be extended to solve aDPCSPs.

Another approach which has recently been developed and applied to the ecological domain by Heller and Struss (1998, 2001). This work derives a system’s structure from observations of its behaviour and domain knowledge. Therefore, it is able to perform diagnosis of ecological systems and therapy suggestion. Another important distinction of this work from the present study is that it presumes that each process can only be described in just one way instead of allowing multiple alternative models. Another approach which has recently been developed and applied to the ecological domain by Heller and Struss (1998, 2001). This work derives a system’s structure from observations of its behaviour and domain knowledge. Therefore, it is able to perform diagnosis of ecological systems and therapy suggestion. Another important distinction of this work from the present study is that it presumes that each process can only be described in just one way instead of allowing multiple alternative models. In the machine learning community, a number of approaches have been devised by Bradley, Easley and Stolle (2001); Langley et al. (2002); and Todorovski and Dz̆eroski (1997, 2001) to induce sets of differential equations from a) observations of behaviour, b) domain knowledge represented in the form of hypothetical equations, and c) a description of the structure of the system.

Another approach which has recently been developed and applied to the ecological domain by Heller and Struss (1998, 2001). This work derives a system’s structure from observations of its behaviour and domain knowledge. Therefore, it is able to perform diagnosis of ecological systems and therapy suggestion. Another important distinction of this work from the present study is that it presumes that each process can only be described in just one way instead of allowing multiple alternative models. In the machine learning community, a number of approaches have been devised by Bradley, Easley and Stolle (2001); Langley et al. (2002); and Todorovski and Dz̆eroski (1997, 2001) to induce sets of differential equations from a) observations of behaviour, b) domain knowledge represented in the form of hypothetical equations, and c) a description of the structure of the system. These approaches aim at scientific discovery by generalising observed behaviour into mathematical models. The specifications of the scenario and the domain knowledge in these methods are similar to those used in this article. This is especially true for the work by Langley et al. (2002); and Todorovski and Dz̆eroski (1997, 2001), because that work has also been applied to population dynamics.

metadata.abstractText: The predominant knowledge-based approach to automated model construction, compositional modelling, employs a set of models of particular functional components. Its inference mechanism takes a scenario describing the constituent interacting components of a system and translates it into a useful mathematical model. This paper presents a novel compositional modelling approach aimed at building model repositories. It furthers the field in two respects. Firstly, it expands the application domain of compositional modelling to systems that can not be easily described in terms of interacting functional components, such as ecological systems. Secondly, it enables the incorporation of user preferences into the model selection process. These features are achieved by casting the compositional modelling problem as an activity-based dynamic preference constraint satisfaction problem, where the dynamic constraints describe the restrictions imposed over the composition of partial models and the preferences correspond to those of the user of the automated modeller. In addition, the preference levels are represented through the use of symbolic values that differ in orders of magnitude.
